name: Banh Mi recipe
description: Recipe video above! See in post for more details and photos about the authentic ingredients, where to source them, and the BEST subs from everyday supermarkets. When combined with everything else, it still tastes like an incredibly authentic Banh Mi!
recipeIngredient: 4 - 8 slices Thi Nguoi ("pink ham") OR brawn ((aka head cheese, Note 4))
4 - 8 slices Cha¬†Lua Vietnamese pork loaf OR chicken loaf ((Note 5))
4 - 8 slices roast or grilled pork cold cuts ((Note 6))
2  cucumbers (, finely sliced lengthwise into long strips)
4  green onion stems (, cut into the length of the rolls)
2  red chillies (, finely sliced (or more!) (or less...))
4  medium carrots (, peeled cut into 2-3mm / 1/10" batons)
3/4 cup (185ml)  rice wine vinegar ((sub apple cider vinegar))

recipeInstructions.text: Split rolls down the centre of the top (see video).
recipeInstructions.name: Split rolls down the centre of the top (see video).

recipeInstructions.text: Spread 1.5 tbsp pate on one side, then 1.5 tbsp mayonnaise on top.
recipeInstructions.name: Spread 1.5 tbsp pate on one side, then 1.5 tbsp mayonnaise on top.

recipeInstructions.text: Layer in the hams, cucumber slices and green onion.
recipeInstructions.name: Layer in the hams, cucumber slices and green onion.

recipeInstructions.text: Stuff in plenty of carrots and coriander sprigs.
recipeInstructions.name: Stuff in plenty of carrots and coriander sprigs.

recipeInstructions.text: Sprinkle with fresh chilli - as much as you dare!
recipeInstructions.name: Sprinkle with fresh chilli - as much as you dare!

recipeInstructions.text: Drizzle with Maggi Seasoning (about 1/2 tsp per roll).
recipeInstructions.name: Drizzle with Maggi Seasoning (about 1/2 tsp per roll).

itemListElement.text: Banh Mi pork meatballs - for each Banh Mi, use 3 meatballs. Shake off excess sauce, split warm meatballs in half then stuff into Banh Mi in place of the ham.
itemListElement.name: Banh Mi pork meatballs - for each Banh Mi, use 3 meatballs. Shake off excess sauce, split warm meatballs in half then stuff into Banh Mi in place of the ham.

itemListElement.text: Shredded cooked chicken - use in place of ham. I often use store bought rotisserie chicken for convenience!
itemListElement.name: Shredded cooked chicken - use in place of ham. I often use store bought rotisserie chicken for convenience!

itemListElement.text: Dissolve  salt and sugar in the hot water, then add rice vinegar.
itemListElement.name: Dissolve  salt and sugar in the hot water, then add rice vinegar.

itemListElement.text: Add carrot, then let stand for at least 1 hour - carrot should be a bit tangy, a bit floppy but still with a soft crunch.
itemListElement.name: Add carrot, then let stand for at least 1 hour - carrot should be a bit tangy, a bit floppy but still with a soft crunch.

review.reviewBody:
Use light soy (=your Golden brand). This is the most ordinary.  Dark soy would be OK too, but not as flavoursome and the colour might intrude on your enjoyment.  

As a general rule, Asian recipes that just say "soy sauce" mean "light soy sauce" and if they meant dark soy they would say it.

My friend got me some rolls in Cabra which means I have to make this Bahn Mi. I use the shredded chicken option and skip the pate because I can‚Äôt replicate the ones you get in the shop.
Huge fan of this recipe in general, thank you!

We are big Marrickville Pork Roll fans and have recently moved away from Sydney so have missed out on our weekend pork roll fix. We decided to try your recipe today with the woolies and coles deli meet substitutes and the pickled carrot. It's SO good. Thanks for sharing this now we don't have to miss out on our Sunday banh mi. We used pate we already had and hellmans Mayonnaise. Honestly so yum

I loveeeeeeeeee Banh Mi, completely addicted to them and finally made this at home last night . it was perfect and hit craving spot perfectly with the roast pork slices from coles. I will be having these at home all the time now! Thanks Nagi
I love Banh Mi. I make my own vegetarian pate and for 'meat' use a plant based 'roast duck' which has a firm texture. Delish!

Thank you so much for this recipe!

I love banh mi but my husband has never been a fan, especially as a coriander hater. I thought making them at home might help him appreciate them more - but it was too successful! 
Now he thinks all other banh mi pale in comparison to our home made ones :D

Your notes are always so helpful and well researched. As I'm not keen on pork I use your lemongrass chicken as the meat in it, and sriracha as the drizzle. And plenty of coriander on mine only!!! Sooo good, thank you Nagi!

I I‚Äôm just back from Vietnam yesterday and ¬¥m already missing the country and the food. Therefore I decided to do a Banh Mi for lunch following carefully your receipt. It was just delicious and reminding me the great flavour of Vietnam. So thanks a lot for this great and very well explained receipt üëåüòÅ

I want to thank you for this recipe, it's brilliant! Everything is detailed and easy to follow, and ingredients are adaptable to whatever is available locally. 

We're still stuck in (more-or-less) locked down Sichuan, China - and this recipe, with a fair bit of chopped, fresh xiaomila and occasionally homemade char sui, has become our favourite homemade dinner when I'm getting an urge for something *bread* instead of the usual Sichuan fare.

Omg I did both Vietnamese meatballs & pork belly for a Bahn mi casual lunch amazing 
results loved by all 
I have mad so many reciptineats meals & they are soooo good I wld suggest for someone who is not familar with cooking to try your recipes Nagi your explanations & presentation of recipes is the best & wld give any new cook confidence I am 71 & love cooking/entertaining & you r amazing
